newsitem.title: UK: Wetherspoon to create 10,000 pub jobs.
newsitem.headline: Wetherspoon to create 10,000 pub jobs.

text.p: Ambitious pub operator J.D. Wetherspoon Plc on Tuesday announced a major expansion plan which should create 10,000 jobs across Britain within the next five years.
The company, which currently operates 170 pubs and employs 5,500 people, said it wanted to open another 350 outlets by 2001 to grow outside its London roots.
Wetherspoon, floated five years ago, said its plan would lead to 4,500 fulltime and 5,500 part-time jobs, ranging from pub managers to bar and kitchen staff.
"Our jobs programme is one of the biggest in the pub industry and will be a major boost for many regions," said chairman Tim Martin, who founded Wetherspoon in 1979.
The company's share price closed at 1,177 pence, down from the previous close of 1,187-1/2.
The company has grown by transforming derelict buildings such as former banks, cinemas and post offices into pubs featuring no music, but including large non-smoking areas.
"Our pubs...have proved extremely popular and we are looking to build on this success," Martin said. "We are irresistible to pub goers."
Wetherspoon's expansion plan comes a month after the company reported a 46 percent increase in its first-half pre-tax profit to 8.1 million pounds.
The company, which first moved outside London four years ago, will finance its expansion mainly through cash flow, but also with loan capital.
